--- title: "World Politics" subtitle: "Historical Background" author: - Michael Flynn institute: - Department of Political Science - 011C Calvin Hall - meflynn@ksu.edu - "Last Updated 2025-01-21" execute: warning: false message: false format: revealjs: theme: [quarto-lecture-theme.scss, default] #css: quarto-lecture-theme.css slide-number: true chalkboard: true height: 900 width: 1600 margin: 0.1 fig-cap-location: bottom tbl-cap-location: top #incremental: true fig-width: 8 fig-height: 6 title-slide-attributes: data-background-image: "ksu-seal.png" data-background-size: 45% data-background-position: bottom -38% right -19% --- ## Lecture Overview 1. Origins of the modern state 2. Mercantilist Era 3. Pax Britannica 4. Thirty Years' Crisis 5. Cold War 6. Post-Cold War ## ### Key Questions and Goals 1. What is a "state" and where did the modern state come from? 2. Identify factors that contributed to the growth of human settlements and uneven development across space and time. 3. Be able to define some of the key events that define each time period. 4. Identify the major actors driving events during each time period. 5. How did finance, monetary policy, and conflict all relate to one another during these time periods? # Origins of the Modern State ## Origins of the Modern State ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](historical-background_files/figure-revealjs/Global Population-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Origins of the Modern State Lots of people, how to organize? - Individual - Nuclear family - Bands and extended family - Chiefdoms, tribes, and clans - Cities - City-states and Kingdoms - Empires - Nation-states ## Origins of the Modern State So what defines a nation-state? A few key characteristics: - Functional differentiation - State consists of offices and emphasizes specializations - More efficient when someone specializes in something - Office is more important than a single person and persists beyond the current occupant - State enjoys a monopoly on the use of violence within its territory (i.e. violence is public, not private) - Territorial sovereignty -- Lots of different ways to arrange and organize - Democracies - Autocracies - Presidential systems - Parliamentary systems - Imperialist/non-imperial ## Origins of the Modern State So what determines how and why people organize? Lots of things: - Biology (e.g. family relations, kin groups) - Basic incentives for cooperation (Protection, division of labor, etc.) - Technological adaptations (domestication of animals, agriculture, etc.) - Force and violence - Geography ## Origins of the Modern State Agricultural Revolution: - Domestication of plants happens ~12,000 years ago - Different peoples and regions begin developing agricultural systems at different times - Hunter/gatherer and agriculture two strategies and develop alongside one another :::{.notes} Notes Agricultural Revolution - Begins around 10,000 BCE (~12,000 years ago) - We shouldn’t think that agriculture just spontaneously developed at this point in time. It’s beginnings can be traced roughly to this era, but it unfolds over thousands of years. - 9000 BC in Middle East - 7000 BC in East Asia - 4500 BC in Central America - 2000 BC in North America - Development of agriculture proceeds at different pace in various regions across the globe. - Some settle to live off land and farm permanently - Some live as hunter-gatherers and farm seasonally - Some live as hunter-gatherers full time - We should think of these as two strategies, and historically they were typically mixtures are employed. They’re not mutually exclusive. Overall trend through time, though, is towards agriculture and farming. Advantages and Disadvantages: - Agriculture typically requires a long time-frame (you could starve waiting for some plants to yield food) - Some crops have better/worse yields. Examples of high-yield crop groups include: - Cereals/Grains (wheat, barley, millets, rice) - Pulses (peas, soybeans, peanuts, chickpea) - These crops also grow quickly - Other crops, like lettuce, take a lot of time and space to grow, and they aren’t even that nutritionally dense. ::: ## Origins of the Modern State Domestication of Animals - Begins around the same time with dogs (then sheep, goats, pigs, cows, and horses) - Increases food supply (and it's renewable) - Facilitates greater diversification and specialization of labor - Food surpluses mean populations can grow more quickly - Population can also congregate in one place - Larger populations require more animals means more disease (e.g. flu, tuberculosis, malaria, plague, etc.) ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} `````{=html}
Percent of Large Animals Domesticated
Category Eurasia Sub-Saharan Africa Americas Australia
Candidates 72 51 24 1
Domesticated Species 13 0 1 0
Percent Domesticated 18% 0% 4% 0%
1 Candidates are defined as species of terrestrial, herbivorous, or omnivorous, wild mammals weighing on average over 100lbs. See Diamond (1997, 162)
````` ::: ::: :::{.notes} Notes Subordinating other species - Cooperation can be beneficial for agricultural development, but it can also be inter-species relationships. - Begins very early (~12,000 years ago for big animals) - Roots of domestication can be seen in hunter-gatherer societies - Dogs among first animals to be domesticated from wolves - Evidence indicates that some wolves would follow roving humans and feed off their scraps. Wolves with less flight instinct would benefit more from closeness to humans, as they’d be among the first to approach and get scraps. - Six Criteria for Domestication (Jared Diamond Guns, Germs, and Steel (1997)): - Diet: How much food does it require? - Dogs are omnivores and can survive on different foods. Lions require 17–20 lbs/day. - Growth Rate: How fast? Dogs grow up quickly. Animals like elephants do not. Almost two years for a n elephant to be born!. - Captive Breeding: Some animals don’t breed in captivity. For example, Cheetahs are incredibly difficult to breed in captivity. - Disposition: Will they kill you? Are they aggressive? Think bears, zebra. - Temperament: Do they panic? Deer and other such animals have a very low flight threshold. The can scare easily and die in captivity. - Social Hierarchy: Can humans become the alpha? Are they susceptible to herd- ing? Dogs are great at this, and we know in fact that their organizational behavior has adapted to life around humans by taking on a more hierarchical form of pack relations. ::: ##

This is Atlas. The headband he ordered arrived today. Has no plans of ever taking it off so he hopes you like it. 14/10 would pet-al day long pic.twitter.com/FGw08ayjmP

— WeRateDogs® (@dog_rates) August 19, 2018
This is Atlas. The wondrous culmination of millennia of domestication efforts. :::{.notes} Notes Domestication vs. Taming: - Domestication implies the animal is captured and is bred in captivity for human purposes. - Taming implies the animal is captured and brought under human control, but never modified in any fundamental way. - Many different species are tamed and some used for hunting (Monkeys, Cheetah, Bears, Eagle, etc.) - Actual domestication is highly skewed towards Eurasia - Dogs in North America are among the first animals to be domesticated - Genetic evidence links modern dogs to wolves - Recent research suggests wolves are more communal/cooperative, but dogs are more submissive. Humans likely selected for submissive traits when breeding. Wolves tend to share food, while dogs with higher status in pack have greater access. [See Science Magazine article](news.sciencemag.org/brain-behavior/2014/08/wolves-cooperate-dogs-submit-study-suggests) ::: ## Origins of the Modern State Geography also matters - Determines where people travel, hunt, settle, farm, etc. - Determines the availability of flora and fauna - Determines how plentiful supporting infrastructure can be - Also determines the supply of diseases ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](historical-background_files/figure-revealjs/Acemoglu and Robinson-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: # The Mercantilist Era ## The Mercantilist Era Overview - The modern nation-state system is often traced to the **Peace of Westphalia in 1648** > Peace of Westphalia: The settlement that ended the Thirty Years' War in 1648: Often said to have created the modern state system because it included a general recognition of the principles of sovereignty and nonintervention (FLS, 8). - Focused mainly on Western Europe - Intra-European competition preceeds this point in time, and persists long after - Polities are scrambling to establish overseas colonies ## The Mercantilist Era Who are the major players during this period? - England - France - Spain - Portugal - The Netherlands (the Dutch) - Ottoman Empire - China - Japan - Mughal Empire :::{.notes} Notes Note that most of the European powers were focused on sea power when projecting power overseas, as well as small bands of mercenaries, and later corporations that were functional appendages of the state. Sharman. (2019) also notes that they focused more on credit for financing military operations. Land empires in Asia were less interested in maritime power projection, had large and successful land-based militaries, and were also able to finance much of their military activity directly from treasury funds. ::: ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](https://www.netquest.com/hubfs/Imported_Blog_Media/vhsbeta-1.png) ::: ::: :::{.notes} - We need to be careful when inferring outcomes as deterministic or pre-determined. - We often view history through the lens of European history, discussing the rise of European powers and European dominance as a clear consequence of earlier decisions or conditions. - But sometimes the contemporaneous view is far less clear. European powers had strengths and weaknesses as did Asian powers. Some of the oft-discussed answers to European dominance don't hold up under scrutiny (e.g. Asian powers embraced firearms technology, adapted strategies and tactics, and did quite well against European forces on land and at sea.) - VHS and Beta max - Both technologies had advantagers - Beta had better resolution - VHS had longer recording times ::: ## The Mercantilist Era But what **IS** Mercantilism? > Mercantilism: An economic doctrine based on a belief that military power and economic influence were complements. Applied especially to colonial empires int he 16th through 18th centuries. Monopolies at the center of mercantilist trade policies favored the mother country over its colonies and over its competitors (FLS, 5) ## The Mercantilist Era ::::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} Examples of mercantilist policies: - Colonialism - Monopolies - Restrictions on trade - Tariffs - Quotas ::: :::{.column width=50%} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](../../media/AdamSmith.png){width=80%} ::: ::: ::: :::: :::{.notes} Notes Examples of Mercantilist policies: - Colonialism: The direct territorial conquest of another part of the globe. Typically characterized by direct political and military rule by the imperial power. British government directly controlled the American colonies. Often used to extract raw materials and to provide markets for finished goods. - Monopolies: Government-granted exclusivity to merchants/company/corporations to operate in a particular area or trade. Government-backed firm is the sole supplier, thereby driving up prices on the goods in question. Would-be competitors are driven out of business by the state. The state benefits from the higher prices in the form of duties or taxation. Rents—the government uses its authority to extract rents from the corporation, and ultimately from consumers. - Restrictions on trade - Import tariffs: Taxes on imported goods. - Quotas: Limits on how much of a particular good can be imported for a given amount. - Colonies have a wide range of benefits - Food: E.g., England or Japan. Limited territory. Agricultural development may be limited in some areas. - Raw materials: Similar to previous point. Limited resources are available in some territories. Geography! - Slaves and forced labor: Labor is essential to increase production prior to the industrial revolution. Also, conscription during times of war. Thousands of Indian soldiers were conscripted by the British during WWI. - Prestige: Think “the sun never sets on the British Empire”. Overseas colonies can also provide access (potentially exclusive) to rare goods not found in Europe. Tobacco for example. - Land / Territory: See previous points on resources. Can also serve to enhance power projection capabilities. Supply depots, military bases, etc. - Markets: Markets: Home state depends upon foreign markets to soak up the goods the home state produces. American colonies buying British tea. - Example of American colonies: - Colonies could only import manufactured goods from Britain - Colonies could only sell some goods, like tobacco, to Britain - Taxes levied on American colonists at the end of the French and Indian War (Seven-Years’ War) were intended to help recoup costs associated with waging war on the French. The writings of Adam Smith are a direct response to this time period. - This also represents another misuse of history. Smith's writings are often presented as a wholesale rejection of government. Not so. Smith advocated for government and taxation to play a role in places where individual profit-seeking was insufficient to provide what people need. - He was mostly opposed to protection and tariffs. He viewed them as inefficient, and viewed the pursuit of colonies as a dangerous endeavor that put nations and their people at risk of war. - Capitalism was in many ways contrary to the established order because it sought to position the locus of economy activity somewhere other than landholding elites. ::: ## The Mercantilist Era End of the Mercantilist Era - United States emerges as an independent nation in 1783 - French Revolution begins in 1789 - Napoleon rises to power, then defeated in 1815 at Waterloo - Great Britain rises to hegemonic status > Hegemony: The predominance of one nation-state over others (FLS, 8). # The Pax Britannica ## The Pax Britannica What is the *Pax Britannica*? - Literally, the "British Peace" - Approximately 1815–1914, from the end of the Napoleonic Wars to the beginning of World War I - Congress of Vienna: - Creates a post-war order in Europe - Emphasizes balance of power on the continent - France remains a continental power - Creates a system of consultation among European leaders - Partly rooted in fears of democratic revolutionaries ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](historical-background_files/figure-revealjs/interstate wars-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## The Pax Britannica British egemony has two pillars - Naval power - Economic power British government also worked to maintain a balance of power among continental European powers ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](historical-background_files/figure-revealjs/industrial metrics-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](historical-background_files/figure-revealjs/military personnel metrics-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## The Pax Britannica Global Economic Relations - Technological innovations increase efficiency and productivity - Britain leads other nations in move to free trade by relaxing protectionist/mercantilist restrictions - Allow imports from other countries - Increasingly search for markets to which they can export their own goods - Tariff reductions throughout the 1800s :::{.notes} Notes - Technological innovations increase efficiency and productivity. Wealth is moving from the landed elites to urban manufacturers. - Steam technology helps to increase trans-Atlantic transit time. - First hybrid sail/steam ship crossed Atlantic in 1818. Doesn’t start to take off until about 1840. - Transit time could be 6–10 weeks by sail. Steam cut it down to 7–14 days by early 1900s. Record is 3–4 days. - Ships were faster, but also became larger. Carry more people and goods. ::: ## The Pax Britannica Wait, what are these words you keep using? > **Protectionism**: Policies aimed at protecting domestic industries, often by blocking competing imports from other countries or using subsidies to prop up domestic industries. > **Tariff**: A tax on imported goods paid by consumers. A major tool used to advance protectionist policies. > **Subsidies**: Spending by governments to help businesses defray the costs of operating. ## The Pax Britannica ::::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} Example: The "Corn Laws" - Impelemented in England in 1815 - Protects domestic agricultural production by taxing imported agricultural goods - Raises the costs of imports, making domestic goods more attractive - Repealed in the 1840s ::: :::{.column width = 50%} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Object: The Blessings of peace or, the curse of the Corn Bill. Wealthy landowners reject wheat, saying they don't care how cheap it is and that the poor can starve if they can't afford it. Poorer people in the picture comment that they'll quit their native country. Print made by: George Cruikshank Published by: S W Fores. https://www.britishmuseum.org/collection/object/P_1868-0612-1281](../../../media/corn-law-cartoon.png){width=100%} ::: ::: ::: :::: ## The Pax Britannica The/A Gold Standard - Britain returned to a gold standard in 1819 to help reduce inflationary pressures following the Napoleonic Wars - Facilitated the move to free trade - Essentially acted as a common currency - This becomes more "global" around the 1870s. Many states bi-metallic before this. :::{.notes} Notes Britain returned to gold in 1819 to help reduce inflationary pressures following Napoleonic Wars. Government wanted to maintain faith of creditors. Monetary policy partially designed to help stabilize currency and prevent inflation by tying currency to gold. ::: ## The Pax Britannica Stop—what are these terms again? > **Monetary Policy**: Pertains to how a country manages the production, supply, and valuation of their currency/money. Not the same as spending and budgets (that's fiscal policy) > **Gold Standard**: A system where a country's currency (money) is backed by gold and is convertable at a certain rate. > **Free Trade**: The relaxation or elimination of protectionist policies (it's a matter of degree, not a binary condition). > **Bi-Metalism**: A monetary systen in which countries use multiple metals to back their currency (e.g. gold *and* silver) ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](historical-background_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-4-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: :::{.notes} Notes How can trade be more than 100% of GDP?! It's all in how we count: $$ GDP = \text{Private Consumption}_{it} + \text{Investment}_{it} + \text{Government Spending}_{it} + (\text{Exports}_{it} - \text{Imports}_{it}) $$ So if total trade (i.e. imports plus exports) is very large then it can exceed overall GDP. In the following example exports are huge, but so are imports, and together they total to 175 (i.e. total trade). Example: $$ 100 = 25 + 25 + 25 + (100 - 75) $$ ::: ## The Pax Britannica Except the Pax Britannica isn't so peaceful for everyone - A new wave of imperialism picks up in the mid-1800s - States are seeking access to resources - Looking for new markets - Also motivated by nationalism, prestige, etc. ## The Pax Britannica ::::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} King Leopold II of Belgium - Belgium colonized the Congo in Central Africa - Extracted natural resources like rubber - Also committed terrible atrocities - Disfigured workers who performed poorly - Massacred thousands (possibly many more) ::: :::{.column width=50%} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![A statue of King Leopold II of Belgium covered in spaypaint during 2020 Black Lives Matter protests in Belgium. https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/europe/belgium-king-leopold-statue-who-colonial-africa-congo-black-lives-matter-a9560291.html](https://static.independent.co.uk/s3fs-public/thumbnails/image/2020/06/11/10/leopold-statue.jpg){width=80%} ::: ::: ::: :::: :::{.notes} - This picture shows again how our field of vision matters. - The BLM protests can be interpreted in a certain way if we view it primarily as a function of US politics and history. - We might draw very different lessons if we see similar protests errupting around the world over similar themes. ::: # The Thirty Years' Crisis ## The Thirty Years' Crisis Approximately 1914–1945 - Covers World War I, Interwar period, and World War II - Roots of the crisis in a number of major events from the 1800s - German and Italian unification disrupted the distribution of power in Europe - Fighting over colonies - Ethnic nationalism increasing in Eastern Europe as Ottoman Empire weakens - Rising German power challenges British dominance ## The Thirty Years' Crisis World War I - 1914–1918 - Central Powers: Germany, Austria-Hungary, Ottoman Empire - Allied Powers: France, Britain, Russia, Italy, Japan, US (Eventually), and others. - War quickly becomes a stalemate - United States enters the war in 1917 helping to break stalemate ## The Thirty Years' Crisis Treaty of Versailles - Officially ends major hostilities - Creates the League of Nations - Outlines a reparations plan - President Woodrow Wilson guides US negotiations, but domestic opposition in US prevents US approval of the treaty ## The Thirty Years' Crisis ::::{.columns} :::{.column width=50%} Costs of the war: - 15 million+ dead - Collapse of several old imperial systems (Ottoman, Austro-Hungarian, Russian, German) - European economies in ruins - Lays the groundwork for World War II ::: :::{.column width=50%} ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Children playing with a pile of Deutchemarks after World War I. Image provided by FLS.](../../../media/Worpol3_Art_JPEG/ch01/WORPOL3_FIGUN01.p22.jpg){fig-align='center' width=50%} ::: ::: ::: :::: :::{.notes} Notes Note that we often look at inflation as the worst part, but historian Adam Tooze notes that the deflation was actually the most crippling part of the post-War economic struggles. ::: ## The Thirty Years' Crisis World War II - Germany angered by the post-War settlement - Great Depression brings inreasing economic isolation (Autarky) - Rise of Fascism in Germany, Italy, Spain, and Japan - These same countries begin building up their militaries and colonizing territories in thei near-abroad :::{.notes} Notes 1. 1933, "Begins" with Japan invading Manchuria in 1933 2. 1938, Germany annexes Austria in 1938 3. 1939, Occupies Czechoslovakia and invades Poland in 1939 4. 1940, Germany invades France 5. 1941, Germany invades Soviet Union and Japan bombs Pearl Harbor ::: ## The Thirty Years' Crisis Costs of the war: - $\approx$ 55 million deaths - $\approx$ 25 million combat fatalities - $\approx$ 20 million deaths from starvation and malnourishment - $\approx$ 7 million victims of the holocaust. Mostly Jews but also other racial and ethnic minority groups, people with disabilities, and more. - European infrastructure and economies in total ruins - US and USSR emerge as the sole super powers # The Cold War ## ::: {.cell layout-align="center"} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Emerging factions during the Cold War period. Image provided by FLS.](../../../media/Worpol3_Art_JPEG/ch01/WORPOL3_MAP01.04.jpg){fig-align='center' width=75%} ::: ::: ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](historical-background_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-8-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## The Cold War Economic (Re)Organization The Marshall Plan - US provides $14 billion+ in aid to Western European Countries - Promotes economic recovery and provides food aid - Also intended to curb Communist inroads Bretton Woods System - US Promotes a restructuring of the global economy emphasizing free trade and global economic integration as a reaction to the interwar period - General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) - International Monetary Fund (IMF) - International Bank for Reconstruction and Development (World Bank) ## The Cold War Nuclear Weapons - USSR denonates its first weapon in 1949 - Destructive power of East and West blocs increases steadily - Growing number of weapons - More destructive capabilities per weapon (e.g. MIRVs) - Concept of Mutually Assured Destruction (MAD) ## The Cold War Proxy Wars - US and USSR fight constantly, but typically not directly - Provide aid, training, and weapons to insurgencies and governments around the world - Sometimes they directly engage each other's proxies (e.g. US in Vietnam, USSR in Afghanistan) - Enables a lot of bad behavior by bad regimes ## The Cold War Decolonization - Remnants of the old imperial systems are swept away - Dozens of newly independent countries enter the international system - Many struggle to overcome legacies of colonialism and domestic coalitions struggle for power ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](historical-background_files/figure-revealjs/unnamed-chunk-9-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: # Post-Cold War ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![Fall of the Berlin Wall, November 9, 1989.](https://dynaimage.cdn.cnn.com/cnn/c_fill,g_auto,w_1200,h_675,ar_16:9/https%3A%2F%2Fcdn.cnn.com%2Fcnnnext%2Fdam%2Fassets%2F191107162239-berlin-wall-fall-1.jpg){width=80%} ::: ::: ## Post-Cold War Globalization - Increasing flows of information, technology, trade, investment, etc. - Barriers to trade and investment lowered through coordinated policy actions - Non-state actors proliferate and grow in power and influence - Development of the "Global South" becomes increasingly important policy issue ## ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ![](historical-background_files/figure-revealjs/global trade-1.png){width=768} ::: ::: ## Post-Cold War Terrorism and transnational actors - September 11 terror attacks - Wars in Afghanistan and Iraq - Rise of Islamic State of Iraq and Syria (ISIS) - Expanded ant-terror operations in Middle East, Africa, Central Asia, and Southeast Asia Rise of China - Changing balance of power in the international system - Potentially revisionist in its approach to global institutions - Increasingly challenging US global military dominance ## Post-Cold War Other major policy issues: - Environmental - Climate change - Global warming - Pollution - Deforestation - Mass migration - Climate migrants - Refugees fleeing organized crime, civil war, etc. - Seeking economic, political, and religious freedom - Global health - Swine Flu - Ebola - COVID-19 - Vaccine/PPE/Treatment distribution and equity
